column5:
Machine learning when paired with biological data has the potential to forever change the way we face diseases including cancer, says @cjimmylin of @Freenome. 

But there will be challenges along the way as Lin outlines in this Q&A. üëá https://t.co/i1QMiLoZPD

Instead of companies stuffing themselves on SaaS, @AndrejSafundzic argues for a new kind of software diet.

One that changes the priorities of IT, security, and procurement from fixing problems to helping them create infrastructure that empowers employees. https://t.co/w8r1QK8P0X

Cities have been called "the largest technology we make." üåÉ

We should be asking these questions, then, before building them, says @zachcaceres.

"Is it expensive to run?"
"Does it scale?"
And especially: "How good are its APIs?" https://t.co/GMiwunnJf4

37signals (Basecamp/HEY) CEO @jasonfried advocates "short-term thinking" when running a company. 

No long-term plans. No to-do lists. You make decisions in the moment and the maximum amount of time devoted to any project is 6 weeks. 

He explains why üëá https://t.co/T21hjknVa9

In the same way e-commerce has decimated many physical stores, @chris_herd believes virtual companies will crush office-based companies. 

Read more: https://t.co/ZevnENO4H7

For companies that have gone or are planning to go to a hybrid-remote model, @chris_herd explains why "hybrid" needs to mean the same thing to management and employees, because it often doesn't. https://t.co/uAn6EckOQe

Far too many products fail because there‚Äôs simply no demand for them. How does that happen? By overlooking user research. 

@Sprig founder @ryanglasgow provides a blueprint for investment in research to fuel the right decisions at every stage of growth. https://t.co/9Wq7J7H5Sa

When your startup is on the line, SuperGoals create focus, says @anchor founder @mignano.

SuperGoals have an urgent timeframe, an open-ended method of achievement, and a single measure of success. https://t.co/waKGxhjlYY

New models for synthetic embryos have recently emerged, but bioengineers aren‚Äôt growing humans now.

The immediate goals, explains @Cambridge & @Caltech scientist @ZernickaGoetz, are to understand how life is created and teach us how to rejuvenate tissues. https://t.co/zI4qqzZybJ

How to break the cycle of technology panics:

Instead of being reactive, science should be proactive. If researchers need 5 years to begin understanding something, the process shouldn‚Äôt start while everyone‚Äôs hyped up and politicians are demanding answers. https://t.co/P52nJni3f0

The Sisyphean cycle of technology panics (and how to break it).

In his new book, @heyfeifer writes about @OrbenAmy‚Äôs four-step theory for what keeps happening when a new technology takes hold, especially with young people. https://t.co/OM1VoEgCkK

No long-term planning. No politics. No Zoom. No 10-12 hour days. No project managers. Fully remote.

@jasonfried shares his unconventional approach to running agile companies. https://t.co/T21hjknnkB
Founder & CEO of @Firstbase, @chris_herd, explains why he believes remote startups will win the war for top talent: https://t.co/ZevnEO5G5H https://t.co/XHjnhItsoJ

For specific metrics investors want to see for marketplaces, social apps, subscriptions, and e-commerce startups, and answers to some frequently asked questions, read more from @venturetwins ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/spni1qTNVT

Data Room Red Flags üö© üö© üö©

Your data room doesn't need to be perfect, but here are a few things that will give investors pause. https://t.co/q8zPfmvAnO

What shouldn‚Äôt you include in your data room?

Five things often seen in data rooms that @venturetwins wouldn‚Äôt recommend including, unless an investor specifically asks for them. https://t.co/VAVOWGSaSp

Lifetime value / Customer acquisition cost: are you making money on the average customer, after accounting for the costs of acquiring and serving them?

Payback period: a measure of how long it takes for the profit generated by the customer to ‚Äúpay back‚Äù the cost of acquisition. https://t.co/ItiNoqvaxc

Usage data ‚Äî this will vary based on type of company, but in general you‚Äôll want to include:

‚úÖ How your user base is scaling over time
‚úÖ Where you are acquiring users and cost
‚úÖ How often and long users are engaging with the product
‚úÖ How users are retaining over time https://t.co/RlCZ1aLlrx

Historical P&L and burn:

The path from gross revenue through net income (loss) through cash outflow on a monthly basis. Break out different types of revenue (if applicable) and major costs. Add your cash balance if you‚Äôre not including a balance sheet and cash flow statement. https://t.co/CsoBVRIW9C

Pitch deck:

At a minimum, this should include your company‚Äôs thesis, product vision, competitive landscape, traction, and team, as well as a rough road map or plan for how you will use the funds.

These are the top 5 things @venturetwins recommends including in your data room:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Pitch deck
2Ô∏è‚É£ Cap table
3Ô∏è‚É£ Historical P&L and burn
4Ô∏è‚É£ Usage data (growth, acquisition channels, engagement, retention)
5Ô∏è‚É£ LTV/CAC and payback period

What is a data room?

In the 1900s, companies used to print physical documents and present them to investors in secure rooms. 

Today, data rooms are virtual ‚Äî but they‚Äôre still an important part of the diligence process. https://t.co/spni1qTNVT

A startup‚Äôs data room is key for raising venture capital. But many founders waste time compiling data investors don‚Äôt want or need.

From @venturetwins, a üßµ on what founders need to know, including specific data investors want to see, info to leave out, and traps to avoid.üëá

Companies that don‚Äôt adapt will bleed talent to their competition, and companies that embrace remote work will replace the ones that don‚Äôt.

Read more from @chris_herd ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/YgZwyFOeNJ

The office has also grown to become a distraction factory of epic proportions. The open office has become the enemy of deep, focused work.

A slew of research has found that the open office leads to higher stress and less productivity. https://t.co/31jFyITVf3

One reason:

On average, US workers commute nearly 30 minutes each way, stealing time from hobbies and relationships outside of work.

‚ÄúWe have a special culture and we need the social connection of the office.‚Äù

A Gartner survey of 5,000 workers found that remote and hybrid employees actually reported higher culture satisfaction than on-site employees. https://t.co/TTJ0eRiXBD https://t.co/A2RlTQssm2

‚ÄúWe do our best work around the water cooler.‚Äù

A 2019 study found just 10% of all communications occurred between employees whose desks were more than 500 meters apart. Collaborative value disappears once companies span floors, buildings, or campuses. https://t.co/cuBPuSSAtI

When employees have the freedom and flexibility to organize work around living, rather than living around work, a new paradigm emerges.

And the arguments for returning to the office don‚Äôt hold up.

Jeff Bezos famously said, ‚ÄúYour margin is my opportunity.‚Äù

Now, your office is your competitor‚Äôs opportunity, writes @chris_herd. Any company that‚Äôs less remote than its competitors risks losing its most talented people.

Why remote startups will win the war for top talent üßµüëá

Insights from our Web3 Water Cooler ‚Äî a Slack chat about a trending topic in crypto moderated by editor @jbensonwrites. 

This week @chaserchapman, @austin_hurwitz & @nuzayraesq discuss the intellectual property frameworks surrounding NFTs.

Read more: https://t.co/7dAo0fYvIr https://t.co/wt2SLLqdWH

Over Slack @chaserchapman @austin_hurwitz @nuzayraesq & @jbensonwrites chat about IP frameworks for NFTs.

They tackle the current legal landscape, commercial rights confusion, creative control & more. Plus, examples of innovation & takeaways for builders. https://t.co/xCnKJ9iVDa

It‚Äôs time to raise. 

You make a deck, practice your pitch, and reach out to investors. 

A meeting ends with a request to share your "data room." But what is a data room, and what should be included in it?

@venturetwins with what startups need to know üëá https://t.co/spni1qCKTT

The Merge is almost here. @ethereum's transition to proof of stake is expected to trigger between September 10-20.

What's this mean and what comes next? EF lead coordinator @dannyryan answers all of our questions.

Part 1: https://t.co/XrXXyAECcb
Part 2: https://t.co/qTXDeaJCMg

Around 40% of workers are considering quitting their jobs. 

The Great Resignation (cc: quiet quitting) isn‚Äôt happening because workers don‚Äôt want to work, writes @chris_herd. 

Rather, top talent is leaving companies that don't trust them to work remote. https://t.co/ZevnEO5G5H

Unlike DALL-E for images or GPT-3 for text, there are no generative AI models trained on the vast body of scientific research. If there were, writes @joshmnicholson, plain-language answers to scientific questions would be would be among the first benefits. https://t.co/1peQH5X78l

In his new book, @heyfeifer explores why new technologies often elicit panic, and argues that to truly understand the effect of new tech, the process shouldn‚Äôt start when people are hyped up and demanding answers, it should start before anyone cares. https://t.co/P52nJni3f0

The concern about social media‚Äôs effect on teens might seem like a uniquely modern debate, but this has happened before.

A 1941 report from The Journal of Pediatrics concluded that many children had become addicted to the latest technology: radio. https://t.co/7f7yg7vDWR

New technologies and the desire to compartmentalize identity, curate how we‚Äôre perceived online, and play with different personas has led to a decentralization of our digital identities.

@jradoff explains how this evolution can benefit users and creators. https://t.co/Mw4VA8T0hY
Ben Stokes (@tinyprojectsdev) gives his take on the recent rise of developer side projects, and why they‚Äôve become much more than just a side hustle. https://t.co/pqJdSe5NDv
Devs & creators: what drives you to build a side project?

Headless commerce ‚Äî where you separate the experience layers in a shopping application ‚Äî is the future of online retail. 

@dirkhoerig answers all of our questions about what it is, how it works, and why it‚Äôs good for both consumers and developers. https://t.co/q4lRYNj0DX

Whether it‚Äôs the desire to create, learn, or get rich, there‚Äôs a fundamental change happening with how developers view their projects. 

You used to put side projects on a CV to land a career in tech. Now, side projects can be your career in tech. https://t.co/pqJdSenov3
The tiny project mindset is summed up by @dvassallo, who runs an online community teaching people how to create a portfolio of small bets. https://t.co/XaQ9IYIIwq

Click around on #buildinpublic and you‚Äôll find devs with dozens of links in their bios to the tiny businesses they‚Äôve created. You can join them on a rollercoaster journey of launching a product, gaining users, and even exiting.

Then, a few months later, they‚Äôll do it all again.

Side projects have also let developers tap into the creator economy. 

@benawad has 1.3 million followers watching his project videos across YouTube, TikTok, and Twitter. https://t.co/GT7zMLqAIq

The effort put into an internet project is often detached from its results. Embracing this randomness in practice simply means launching more projects.

A site like @ProductHunt allows you to get an idea on Monday and launch it to thousands of people by Friday.

Building internet projects is like gambling because the excitement before you launch your next idea is addictive; you just don‚Äôt know what will happen.

With no-code resources and tools like Stripe, it‚Äôs easier than ever to write and deploy a project. https://t.co/pqJdSenov3

A random game about flying a small yellow bird between Super Mario pipes exploded into Flappy Bird, netting $50K a day. A dev built Wordle for his GF, it sold to the NY Times for over $1M. How did this happen?

@tinyprojectsdev calls it gambling at the side-project casino üé∞ https://t.co/u3oGRUlsta

One area of copywriting where AI is already having a significant impact is search results. 

@ctwtn explains how AI-generated copy is being used to produce SEO-driven content at scale ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/VPHyngMwfN

Used properly, AI copywriting tools can be a valuable asset in any writer‚Äôs back pocket.

Here are 5 tools that writers and editors can use to train and curate AI-generated content. Some are better at grammar and spelling, while others can help with research and conceptualizing. https://t.co/XtBMalt6AX

To fully understand what neuroAI is, how it might start to evolve and impact our lives, how it complements other innovations and technologies, and what is needed to push it forward, read @patrickmineault‚Äôs piece ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/A0pu7HTs6t

In the realm of accessibility, neuroAI could help the estimated 10% of the global population affected with dyslexia by designing fonts that are both aesthetically pleasing and easier to read. 

With the right data, fonts could be personalized to a specific individual.

The applications of neuroAI go beyond the visual. 

By building machines that can hear like humans, we could democratize music production, giving anyone the ability to communicate the right emotion during a chorus, create an earworm, or make a piece irresistibly danceable.

One of the core tools of neuroAI is using artificial neural nets to create computer models of specific brain functions. 

Using this recipe and repeating iterative testing across brain processes, scientists are building a patchwork of computer models for the brain. https://t.co/kR2UXmVi92

Netflix famously knows which thumbnails work best. Google tested 50 shades of blue for hyperlinks in 2009, leading to a $200M increase in revenue.

But pretty soon AI will be able to predict the best thumbnail or color without any A/B tests. How? An emerging tech called neuroAI. https://t.co/VfYOZtZhVr

While generative AI models like DALL-E can produce creative art and media, they can‚Äôt tell you if that media will communicate a message to the intended audience ‚Äî but neuroAI could.

@patrickmineault explains what that is and how it could impact our lives. https://t.co/A0pu7Ib3v3

How do AI copywriters stack up against humans? How is the increased use of AI writing tools impacting SEO and search results? And how can companies and creators intelligently use this AI copywriting revolution to their advantage? 

@ctwtn explains üëá https://t.co/wMpbzXg1Pd

One common misconception is the idea that ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù and ‚Äúcustomers‚Äù are synonymous terms. They aren‚Äôt. Understanding how they differ is critical. 

Looking to kickstart a community? Begin with @AmberAtherton's quadrant method: https://t.co/CNeavEGSD7 https://t.co/QUZ8mYk1ms

CEO of @PlanetScaledata, @isamlambert talks with Future about what good serverless looks like, who should run Kubernetes, and the emergence of ‚Äúcloud-prem‚Äù. 

Plus, how to become a non-founder CEO, and advice for moving from engineering to management. https://t.co/JvCe3V64bF

Here‚Äôs what you should know about The Merge ‚Äî Ethereum‚Äôs upcoming transition to proof-of-stake.

Future talks with @dannyryan about üëá

What The Merge means for Ethereum: https://t.co/XrXXyAn1kD 

And how The Merge will impact future Ethereum upgrades: https://t.co/qTXDeb1eaQ https://t.co/tm8UYIUP3s

Co-founder & CTO of @Isovalent & @ciliumproject creator @tgraf__ on the growing cloud-native networking ecosystem, trends around Kubernetes adoption and evolution, where infrastructure still needs to improve, and how standardization is driving innovation. https://t.co/toXH8Mz07K

Why right now is such an exciting time to build in aerospace and defense.

A conversation with @HadrianSpace CEO @2112Power, @KTmBoyle, @pmarca & @packyM: https://t.co/u70Ge4ozS2 https://t.co/eyWilkZQfC

The problem, now so drastically different from a decade ago, is not what to read/buy/eat/watch/etc, but figuring out the best thing to read/buy/eat/watch/etc with your limited time and attention.

@sariazout on why the future of search engines is boutique: https://t.co/tCZCsbsvYR https://t.co/yYV4AwgCH2
Get your productivity back: @jlowin explains "negative engineering" and how it can help dev teams find simple fixes and avoid cascading failures. https://t.co/UiUHAHj5Lm
First it was non-PhDs building deep learning models, now prompt-engineering for DALL-E is its own skill. @jeremyphoward of @fastdotai on the rise of domain experts in AI. https://t.co/WesAhuDfaS

Expansion can supercharge growth, but only when executed correctly. 

@venturetwins & @JohnKoelliker talked to marketplace operators from companies like Instacart, Airbnb, and Depop to learn when, where, and how to expand into new regions and verticals. https://t.co/5YoiwnglUo

MIT's @youngricka, @JorgeCondeBio & @omnivorousread discuss what's been learned about the 98% of the genome once thought as junk ‚Äî from hiding the evidence of ancient viral infections to making every face unique, and the discovery of a gene on/off switch. https://t.co/hjMOuDzIwi

Nitin Natarajan, @CISAgov deputy director, explains how the agency looks at identifying, mitigating ‚Äî and sometimes accepting ‚Äî cybersecurity risks in everything from small-town school districts to internet-connected smart refrigerators. https://t.co/vJCGt1jtKM

A successful sales enablement strategy:

-Designs skilling & readiness programs
-Ensures selling on strategy
-Translates analytics into actions
-Simplifies & automates sellers‚Äô journey

@TziokasV on how to build sales enablement that elevates your GTM üëá https://t.co/BY7JBnWXvc

Some of the big ideas, movements, and research areas in crypto and web3 over the last few months.

Here are seven pieces that describe the possibilities of a decentralized future and what is needed to build it. https://t.co/uDLkDyyY4V

Future‚Äôs web3 x science coverage from this year so far, plus some of the major writings and events across the community. 

The DeSci movement is still young, so we include some coverage of web3 and decentralization that provide useful lessons and insights. https://t.co/OT8O0Sek95

What will happen as CRISPR matures? What does a biologically engineered future look like, and do scientists have to ensure these tools are used responsibly? 

Nobel Prize winner Jennifer Doudna (@doudna_lab) & @vijaypande tackle these questions and more. https://t.co/6dYxtakcnW

Revisit our artificial intelligence and machine learning coverage in Future over the first half of this year. 

The world of AI/ML moves very fast, so we'll catch you up on some ‚Äî but certainly not all ‚Äî of the recent major industry developments. https://t.co/1RbX1iPZGp

The size and sophistication of modern algorithmic ranking models makes it impossible to fully understand how they make predictions, writes @turtlesoupy, who built Instagram‚Äôs first content ranking system, but social platforms can still be more transparent. https://t.co/FSOqtcG2CI

Game creators, building on game tech and using game production processes, will be the key to unlocking the potential of the metaverse, writes @gwertz. He outlines a vision for the changes coming to games and the innovation needed to kickstart this new era. https://t.co/C3lOCuJxIB

Founder & CEO of @insitro, @DaphneKoller joins Future's @DrNikkino for a Q&A on: 

-Building a company culture that fosters collaboration
-The challenges of creating accurate ML models from bio data
-Why data availability is behind the success of AlphaFold
https://t.co/O7hh06a9DO

10/ ‚ÄúLearn to code‚Äù is a tired response to people who don‚Äôt see a place for themselves in the future of work. But, as @itunpredictable writes, there‚Äôs always going to be a need for those who achieve technical literacy. https://t.co/4FmfK8HNL1

8/ Flexport founder @typesfast has been one of the most sought after voices when it comes to understanding global supply chains. For Future, he explains the interplay between software and the real world and the effect on shipping infrastructure. https://t.co/R8gFu9Rga1

Part 1: https://t.co/a4gtnO4Q2J

5/ One of our favorite creator economy writers, @runciedan, explains how companies that group all ‚Äúcreators‚Äù together could miss out on the next phase of opportunities: specific tools that help breakout stars grow their business.

There are levels to this: https://t.co/UAPotVeMBm https://t.co/CuQVUWtMJn

From @benschecter, who writes about how people will earn income in non-traditional ways by taking actions such as playing games, learning new skills, creating art, or curating content: https://t.co/fwEnNCqRE2 https://t.co/G6Qw5tIq6l

2/ From our first drop, @lennysan‚Äôs essential framework for choosing better north star metrics.

1/ A year ago, we launched https://t.co/eQcOAkaJb4. Thank you to everyone who has contributed pieces and ideas, as well as shared and read what we‚Äôve published. 

To celebrate this milestone, we‚Äôre sharing some of our favorite and most-read articles. üßµüëá

NFT memberships, where fans hold a specific NFT to join a private community and get IRL perks, are on the rise as a viable alternative to subscription and ad-based revenue. 

For creators getting into web3, @petergyang's guide is a great place to start. https://t.co/SgK9vk73PG

How to successfully pull off the acquihire.

Advice and strategies for:
‚úÖ Defining your priorities.
‚úÖ Conducting due diligence.
‚úÖ Deal structure considerations.
‚úÖ Properly integrating the new hires into your existing organization.
https://t.co/Eeiwgt7pM7

The idea of a secure software supply chain ‚Äî how software goes from a developer writing code all the way to the end, and the weaknesses along every link and stage in that pipeline, explained by @kimsterv: https://t.co/O7o1cF7Zfz https://t.co/Jj4qy27DZL

Provectus Algae CEO & founder @NusqeSpanton explains how synthetic biology is being used in the manufacturing space, what makes algae so interesting (and challenging) as a vehicle, and how to avoid the pitfalls that led to a false start for algal synbio. https://t.co/q2CZz6HLzU

After a series of high-profile exploits, secure software supply chains are all the rage right now. @kimsterv explains what this means and why open source is a double-edged security sword. https://t.co/oL8cVcghd3

Startups building emerging tech struggle to work with the Defense Department, argues Jeff Decker, of @Hacking4Defense. 

These companies would do well to spend the summer reading comic books ‚Äî Iron Man, specifically ‚Äî and absorbing some of the lessons. https://t.co/PI8bmurkQQ

A peek into the personally curated feeds and media habits of @shellkennedylon, founder and CEO of @Peanut, an online community to connect women throughout all stages of womanhood. https://t.co/lGi7U3dZ6M

Defense GTM strategies are unique to companies and their products. Applying these Iron Man lessons will inform the defense pathways a company takes, yielding increased revenue, greater defense capabilities, and a stronger economy.

Read more ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/PI8bmurkQQ

Dual-use companies that don‚Äôt want to apply for awards and can‚Äôt make an unmodified commercial sale must do the hard work of talking to potential defense end-users to assess their needs and validate that the company‚Äôs solution is capable of meeting those needs.

Companies without billionaire founders can also replicate the Iron Man model by selling their commercial product to the Pentagon without making any ‚Äî or at least any significant ‚Äî modifications. https://t.co/hmI4BJLTr1

What about startups without billionaire founders? 

The Defense Department has established a host of organizations, programs, and opportunities to improve how it works with companies. https://t.co/7UKk9Yy8bG

The ingredients to the Iron Man recipe:  

1Ô∏è‚É£ civilian entrepreneurs 
2Ô∏è‚É£ using their own $ to develop high-risk capabilities in unproven technology sectors 
3Ô∏è‚É£ outside of government organizations and requirements 
4Ô∏è‚É£ to fill a government use-case

The Iron Man model: giving the Pentagon what it needs, not what it wants. 

From Jeff Decker, program director at Stanford University‚Äôs @Hacking4Defense Project. üßµüëá https://t.co/PI8bmurkQQ

One fundamental error hiring managers make is being so focused on candidates‚Äô skills they forget the importance of building trust early in the process.

Jeff Stump, who leads a16z's talent network, shares his framework for establishing trustworthiness. https://t.co/Wpmn4idRi2
What is negative engineering? @PrefectIO founder @jlowin explains: https://t.co/1eBHrzbgB6 https://t.co/Ng00QK0dnF
Why on-prem software is still big business ‚Äî an interview with @MongoDB CTO @MarkLovesTech: https://t.co/6EoD6w5bK1 https://t.co/PP24Zdog3a
Founder & CEO of @Hopper, @fredlalonde, on super-app ambitions and becoming an everything startup: https://t.co/9JBksbhb58 https://t.co/3UxnpanNYd

A framework for navigating down markets, from @DavidGeorge83 & @justin_kahl: https://t.co/hhDNmQlu8Y https://t.co/zX5CkkW0OX

Plus: making talent scouts work for you, building travel super-apps, the thawing relationship of on cloud vs. on-prem, and the value of ‚Äúnegative engineering‚Äù.

Subscribe here üëá
When major shifts happen, either externally or internally at your organization, that‚Äôs a sign to ReCulture. https://t.co/UEZJ2eQ0kY

One of the mistakes many growing companies make is keeping the same processes and practices they used when they had 20 employees, even though they may now have thousands. 

@MelissaDaimler's advice for leaders on "ReCulturing" as your company evolves üëá https://t.co/xjsITyANUB

Burn and valuation multiples tell you how efficiently and how much you need to grow. But when the fundraising environment changes and getting capital becomes more uncertain, you need to plan for your best, base, and worst case scenarios.
 
Read more ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/hhDNmQD5xy

If your burn multiple isn‚Äôt where you need it to be, there are many ways to improve to grow more efficiently, including right sizing different functions, improving margins, or lowering CAC. https://t.co/s8OFq4jp0s

If a company burns $40M to add $10M of ARR, it would have a burn multiple of $40M/$10M, or 4.
 
Burn multiples are a metric you can evaluate every quarter, and tracking it closely can ensure you stay on plan. https://t.co/ICiPsAnqCs

Now that you have a target ARR, how do you evaluate if your business is growing efficiently to reach it?
 
Burn multiples are the best efficiency metrics for recalibrating when market conditions change because they are all-encompassing of your business activities.
For a primer on startup metrics, go here: https://t.co/ElVgPrNi3q

A $20M ARR business which last raised at $2B see public companies in their space trading at 10x revenue, not 100x.

Adjusting for growth, 15x ARR could be a reasonable valuation for next round.

Goal should be to reach $133M of ARR, $2B divided by 15x ‚Äî with 12 months of runway.

How do you recalibrate your goals for this new lower valuation environment?
 
Figure out what ARR you need to reach to get back to your last round valuation by using estimated change in valuation multiples from public companies + a small premium for faster growth.

An example üëá

A year ago, it was common to see funding valuations for late stage private companies that were 100x of ARR.
 
If you did your last round at $20M ARR, growing 3x, you may have raised at a $2B valuation.
 
But things look very different now. https://t.co/9L2rRgy3d7
For a deeper dive into understanding how valuation multiples work, see this article from @aleximm and @DavidGeorge83. https://t.co/tJ4zkJy8xQ

Public markets provide the best basis for recalibrating private growth valuations because they tend to see the effects of decreased valuations first.
 
Currently, median public company software valuations have dropped from 12x forward revenue to 5x or less, almost a 60% decline.

When the market dips, and valuation multiples are on the decline, founders crave advice that can help quantify the magnitude of the change in valuations and what it means for their next round.
 
@DavidGeorge83 & @justin_kahl provide the diagnostic framework @a16z uses üßµüëá

When the market dips, founders crave advice that helps quantify the magnitude of change in their valuation, what it means for their next round, and how to chart their future course. 

@DavidGeorge83 & @justin_kahl provide the diagnostic framework needed. https://t.co/hhDNmQD5xy
